narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lessons were virtual with studio class that were live and virtual.
Virtual music lessons via Zoom
Live virtual lessons
virtual private lessons and virtual studio class
Violin lessons on Zoom
Virtual live
It was one-on-one lessons.
Zoom private lessons
Virtual one-on-one instrumental and reed-making lessons

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to learn new repertoire and develop skills in musicality and technique.
This semester, I focused on learning how to learn things thoroughly and faster. Prof. Sharp is great about pushing your weaknesses.
Worked on fun new rep
I improved my guitar playing
Better technical control of my instrument; more insight into violin playing in general
I learned techniques to help me practice efficiently, learned new ways of reed making, and continued to gather audition experience.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: the course is very flexible in your learning pace. You get as much as you put into it, and I was able to cover a lot of repertoire this semester. I got personalized feedback and could improve. Studio classes were meaningful to get feedback and listen to other people. I don't see any weaknesses.
Lessons are great! I look forward to them all week.
Wendy Sharp is a great teacher and is very understanding and friendly.
It's individual lessons  it worked very well for me this semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The Zoom settings and the microphone enhanced my learning during the COVID-19 pandemic.
We did the best we could with live virtual lessons - nothing compares to in-person.
Although we missed out on the typical fun community of in-person studio classes, the virtual studio classes and lessons were still very effective.

I would always film videos before class, which I thought worked far better than the spring when I would play live over Zoom. Audio quality was better, and it forced me to reckon with a recording of myself every week.

It's difficult to do instrument lessons over Zoom, simply because the sound quality differs from what one could hear live. However, we used Cleanfeed and both had external microphones, so the sound quality was not bad. I also recorded myself and sent the recordings to my teacher to provide a clear sense of my progress. Making reeds via Zoom is also difficult because diagnosis of reed problems often relies on visual cues as well as sound, but we were able to use the Whiteboard feature to effectively draw reed diagrams.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course if you want to develop your musical craft on a deep level.
Yes, if you are interested in pursuing your musical studies further.
Yes, join Wendy's studio!  It's a lovely community to be in.
Yes, if they want to take lessons.
Yes; music lessons are so valuable, and Yale has wonderful faculty.
